Black. Roasted, ashy nose. Pines there, lemon. Soft smooth texture, surprisingly light for the abv. Roasty, light smokey. Bitter, foresty piny. But smooth all the way. An imperial bipa. Clean, nice one. Chocolate in the finish.-- bb

duft: frisk sød appelsin.kaffe ristet malt kommer bag efter
smag: ristet malt frisk hed kaffe stor bandt smag kommer meget kraftigt til slut med kant af appelsin og citrus eller af dufte mørk chokolade

12oz bottle. Pours a glossy black with a nice mocha head of foam that crowns the goblet I have poured it into. As the head recedes, it leaves behind a sticky tan lacing. The aroma is lots of roast and some hop bitterness. That is a lot of bitterness between the two. The flavors come together nicely - and dont clash with one another the way that some black-IPAs do. The finish is also profoundly bitter, which gives this beer some separation from other beers of the type. A nice demonstration of brewing and blending skill.

.33l bottle @Harrys 
Pours black with low head. Aroma is liquorice, grape fruits, dark malts, coffee, chocolate, 
Flavor is alcohol, roasted malts, caramel notes, coffee, chocolate, liquorice, whisky notes, roasted malts and hops. Some pine.

Tap @ Fermentoren. Pours dark brown blackish with reddish hues. Aromas of licorice, some roast, light coffee, pretty fruity and has some malty and hoppy notes. Taste is pretty roasty, chocolate, licorice, light smoke, dry wood, hops, some malty notes with a pretty sweet, roasty and dry finish.

Extremely complex, fruity, floral, malty, coffee, caramel, carbonation, hops, dry. I enjoy a black and tan as a porter/IPA but this is completely mixed so there is not flavor continuum here to enjoy. I think Id like these beers separate better.

bottle 330ml, pitch black with beige head, that is falling quite fast. Aroma is very stoutish and sweet with notes of milk chocolate, vanilla beans and roasted malt. On the other hand the taste is closer to an IPA with some deep going bitterness and medium sweetness. The finish is ashy with a long lasting bitterness of strongly roasted or even burned malt. Alcohol is good hidden.In general not bad, but body could be fuller. The burned afertaste is quite disturbing and I got the impression of eating an ashtray.

Great pour and good color. Little too strong to begin with and becomes smooth in the end.
aroma of roasted grains and the hoppy aroma is not very apparent

Tap Pour - Black..minimal head - looks fierce. Admittedly, I didnt read the description as well as I should have before imbibing this one...but it came through. More imperial stout than IPA on the nose, there is an underlying bitterness to the sweet, sugary malt...some coffee and vanilla notes as well. Flavor is pretty awesome - coffee notes with vanilla-heavy stout, good level of bitterness provides a great backbone to the heavy malt. Palate is medium-heavy bodied, but quite easy drinking, and the ABV is well hidden. Another encounter with this brewery and another solid win...great stuff, even if it doesnt necessarily conform to the Black IPA moniker applied here.

More intense than expected, im going to wait a bit til i drive home. Bitter ipa shows through. Am now interested in anything evil twin. At keg no 229. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The creamy richness of this brew is hard to match - - then comes roasty sweetness countered and enhanced by pings and pangs of pretty, but still assertive hops. To quote Matthew Arnold, its "a darkling plain swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, where ignorant armies clash by night" but the armies are a pitched battle between frothy rich sweet warm stout and lovely strong hops - - and the brewer is definitely not ignorant. The mouthfeel alone is stratospheric. Note: I did drink this at room temperature and I can recommend the same.

good smokey flavor acrid with more than moderate body and imperial flavor moderated by some ipa. it is the quisen, quisentential aw fuck it its the best goddamn black and tan i ver... ever even imagined.

Bottle (12oz $5) 10% ABV. Nearly black with one finger tan head. Looks like a stout. Aroma was mostly roasted malts. Flavor was also roasty. The IPA part made it seem a little thinned and a bit bitter in the finish.

355ml bottle enjoyed @ home. Pours black with a frothy off-white head. Aroma is coffee, citrus, chocolate malt and roasted malt. Flavour is roasted and slighty bitter. Body is medium, texture is on the thin side, average carbonation. Finish is ashy, roasted and resinous.

This self mixed (50:50) version lost a bit of carbonation, so it seems a bit lifeless. The color is black, brown and white foam from both beers. The smell is not very special, but surprisingly, the imperial IPA actually is not dominated by its stouty counterpart. This beer is impressively balanced. The aftertaste is slightly edited with the bitterness and sweetness, which doesnt fit perfectly, but the rest of the beer is awesome.

Black & Tan from 1/3 of a bottle of Yin and Yang each. Beautiful black color with nice stable beige head, some white parts in the head as well. Pine hops, chocolate, caramel, liquorice, even nutty now, it always switches between the two components. Taste is rich and complex, of cocolate malts, toffee, vanilla, everything of the two individual beers mixed together, and boy, do they fit! A warming bitter finish. Fantastic. I wouldn?t have expected that I like the mix so much better than the individual ones.
On tap at the Party Source in Cincinnati/Kentucky: dark roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, herbal, licorice, tea vibe, sharp. really well done, though dont know that Id have to revisit. 7.4
Bottle from Janes Beer Store, Mountain View, CA. Super roasty aroma, with floral and fruity notes. Taste of licorice, roasty, floral, citrus, molasses, and a long bitter finish. Thick body.

bottle. rather thick black with one finger head. huge beer with huge flavors. strong chocolate/coffee malt base, doesnt seem any less malty than a full on stout. huge hops with citrus quite a bit of bitterness. moderate booze, ass kicker of a beer.
Jet black. Coffee, chocolates and citrus hops. Mouth feel is creamy and taste is roasted coffee, cocoa and hops. Unique

12oz Bottle in Seattle. Rich brown pour. Pretty much what you would expect with a nice blend of heavy stout and imperial IPA. Plenty of heavy malt and roasty alcohol, but also balanced with nice rich hops. A bit chalky overall, with bitter chocolate. Nose is fairly fresh. Works as a Black IPA or as a nice Black and Tan. But still not quite my ideal.

Pours rich, warm sable with a thick and rather persistent tan head. Couldnt look better! Aroma has chocolate, roast coffee, hoppy, and nutty notes. Flavor has the same notes but more of coffee and hops, plus roast malt and a hint of caramel. Hoppy bitterness provides a nice undertone. Firm, smooth texture has some good fizz. A splendid marriage of IPA and stout, to bring balance to your life. And beer.

Bottle at home. Deep brown beer with lovely beige small head. Nose is cocoa and malt. Tastes of chocolate, licorice, roasted malt, some citrus pine, molasses. Smooth and hoppy. Fine blend the stout comes through in lovely way.

Backlog rating. Tap at CBC Brixton, London. It pours a dark brown color, with a small beige head. Aroma is roasty, sweet, chocolatey, with grapefruit and mango. Taste is medium sweet with caramel toffee coffe caramel mango grapefruit dark chocolate vanilla and lactose. Full bodied with lively carbonation. overall, really tasty

Bottle. Aromas of roasted malts and subtle hops. Pours a dark opaque brown. Theres a nice balance of coffee roasts, hops, and some grapefruit. The mix of stout with the hoppy IPA makes this easy to drink at 10% ABV. Very enjoyable taste. Dry hoppy finish that pleasantly lingers.

Bottle: One-third stout & one-third IPA. Pitch black, just a small sliver of dark ruby at the very top, underneath the lathery, foamy tawny cap. Nice sheet of lacing as it recedes. Aroma favors the stout. Heavy roasted malt, charred cacao, & a hint of coffee bean. A touch of smokiness, too. There are some underlying notes of ashy hop leaves, pine, & faint citrus peel. Flavor definitely incorporates more of the IPA. Actually kind of tastes like a black IPA. Lots of pine, herbal leaves, bitter citrus rind, & moderate floral notes over a backbone of heavily roasted malt, charcoal, bitter cocoa beans, & mild smoke. Finishes with a kiss of bitter dark malts, grapefruit pith, ash, & a hint of saltiness. Alcohol becomes slightly noticeable with warmth. The pine flavor grows, too. Overall, though, much better than expected. Like a souped up, heavy-ass black IPA.

Bottle brought home from NYC. Black body with a medium light brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, hops, some tropical fruits in the background. Flavour is dark chocolate, bitter coffee, roasted malt, hops, again some fruit in the background. Wow this is delicious. Thanks for another great brew Jeppe.

400th review and my first Evil Twin. Coffee black pour with a tan head that didnt last long. Earthy hop aromas and some burnt malts. Mellow drinker for the high alcohol and the unique style. Slight smokiness, resin, coffee, and some TLC. Not bad, and if it can be completely considered a Black IPA, then it is one of my favorites.

Poured a clear brown color with a small white head. Aroma was light chocolate notes, sweet roasted malts. Flavor was roasted malts, floral hops. Bitter chocolate notes, light nutty notes. Boozy notes at the end.

BOD 259/14. Pours a slightly transparent near black. Normal head volume, above average retention and excellent lacing. Nose is as advertised - ale characteristics (pine and citrus hops) over stout characteristics (dark chocolate with notes of roast). Underneath are notes of caramel - quite nice. As it warms, alcohol becomes evident as do very subtle notes of dark fruit. Light medium bodied with a nice smooth texture that has a bit of creaminess to it. Above normal carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the middle and more in the finish. The flavor profile is intense, quite complex and reasonably balanced. It begins with a burst of sweetness that rapidly fades into a blended bitterness of hops and roast. As the bitterness fades, grapefruit rind and pine hop flavors become dominant. These, in turn, yield to a mild coffee flavor over a sweet chocolate note. The finish is a lingering rind bitterness over heavy notes of alcohol and hints of prune.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a very, very deep brown with a light tan head.  Somewhat roasty aroma with some more fruity suggestions.  As a "black and tan" it drinks like a Black IPA, with roastiness and an herbal pine hoppiness.  A rather nice one, in fact.

Pours mostly black with a fairly frothy tan head - nose and flavor have a nice mixture of the smoke, anise, and roast of the stout, coupled with stringy woody hop character and bitterness - slick texture - hefty body - it often tastes more like a hoppy imperial stout than a black IPA, a suppose a testament to the stou that is part of the blend - quite tasty.

[6027-20131030] 12floz bottle. Roasty wood chocolate aroma. Clear, dark mahogany red body with a long-lasting creamy mocha head. Sweet roasted chocolate malt flavour has a sweetened coffee feel to it. Full body is fairly bitter. Delicious but a touch rough in the finish. (8/5-/8/4/17) 4.2

12 oz. bottle. Pours black, with a medium, bubbly, tan head. The nose is roasted malts, pine, semi-sweet chocolate, toffee, and subtle honeysuckle. Sweet and malty, with some roasted bitterness, but a substantial hop bitterness. Heavy body, sticky, syrupy, and fairly astringent. This is a nice hoppy, roasted beer. Nicely balanced.

Bière faite maison avec un mix 50/50 dune Yin et dune Yang à la brasserie, couleur noire, mousse magnifique blanche avec des reflets marrons effervescences très moyenne. En bouche belle qualité gustative sur lmande et le houblon. Marrant
Bue en petite quantité. Enorme bonne surprise pour ce blend. Superbe équilibre entre ces 2 bieres qui se complètent et se mélangent tout à fait bien.

50/50 mix. The pale ale clearly dominates. The aroma is mostly Yang - same hoppy fruity notes, and lots of sweet fruity malts - but the impy reduces some of the caramel sweetness. The flavour is fruity malt sweetness, hops and nice chocolaty and roasty accents. The bitterness is strong and somewhat harsh.
12 ounce bottle. Pours black with a decent tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and fruit. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, citrus, and pine. Well balanced. Very good.

Pour is coffee black with a medium thick tan froth. Aroma mostly overpowered with citrus, pine, grapefruit, hops, with a slight background of of the roasted malty notes of the stout. They combined the citrus fruit hoppiness with the roasted coffee chocolateness of the two styles perfectly. Really enjoyed this beer.
Bottle. Lactic chocolate malt and orange peel aroma. Dark brown with small head. Sweet cola, musk, light chocolate malt and light bitter herbal flavor. Nice body. Unique.

355ml bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York. Black in colour with a lasting tan coloured head. The aroma is of chocolate, oranges, some roast. The flavour is of light citrus hops, chocolate, roast and light smoke. Finishes long, moderate bitterness, light alcohol.

Bottle. Roasted malt aroma with notes of chocolate and a some hops. Pours black with a thin light brown head and decent lacing. Starts with good roasted malt and some chocolate, but still medium bodied. Finishes with the dryness and slight citrus hoppiness of an ipa, but also has the roasted maltiness of a stout that sticks to the palate. Interesting take on a Black and Tan.

Bottle:
Pours black with a dark tan head.
Smoke and licorice aroma.
Burned coffee and chocolate flavor.
Big charred/ashy and resiny hop bittering.
This one hits all the marks for the style.
Excellent stuff.
Pours black into a tulip. Tan head with medium retention recedes to hug rim. Licorice and chocolate aromas. Medium bodied with charred chocolate and resin front to back.

On tap @ 10 East
Aroma - seems to angle towards the IIPA territory rather than the expected IS territory. Fruity, lots of pine sap with just a echo of roasted malts. Lurking underneath it all is some wet coffee grounds. Appearance - muddy dark brownish/lack body, scant head. Aggitation provides a 1" tight beige head. Flavor - pine sap and chocolate dominate things, but an ashy/acridness shows up too thats not very pleasing to me. Licorice and dark berries seem to show up too about mid-pint. Palate - full bodied beer, nothing cloying but you can feel some density about it. Overall - I think I like the individual beers better than the combo, but it wasnt bad.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 9/16/2014. Pours pitch black color with a 2 finger dense dark tan head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, orange zest, dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, molasses, licorice, floral, grass, pine, light char/smoke, and floral/roasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/roasted malt and citrus/pine hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, orange zest, dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, molasses, licorice, floral, grass, pine, light char/smoke, and floral/roasted earthiness. Good amount of pine and roast bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, orange zest, dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, molasses, licorice, pine, light char/smoke, and floral/roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of big dark/roasted malt and citrus/pine hop flavors; with a great roasted malt and hop bitterness/sweetness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a very creamy, slick, moderately sticky, and lightly chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice Black and tan style. All around great balance and complexity of big dark/roasted malt and citrus/pine hop flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. Definitely felt like an imperial black IPA with the big hoppiness. Would be interested in aging this one to see what happens. A very enjoyable offering.

Bottle from Maltitude. Pours dark black with frothy tan head. Aroma of dark malt, hops. Taste of strong bitter hops, roasted malts, and a hint of floral. Bitter hops on the back end. Very good black IPA
Black pour from 12oz bottle at home. Malty creamy aroma. Chocolate and vanlla taste. Bitter and hoppy. Perfect combo of stout and ipa. This is delicious. Pine, cocoa, and even a little spicy.

Bottle. Grey, black color, weird two-colored head. Mild aroma of dark malt and hops. Taste of strong bitter hops, but also of roasted malt. This combination works quite well, I like this more than the seperate beers. This black & tan results in a fine black IPA.

Bottle. Black pour with a short tan head. Aroma is roasted malt and floral hops with hop resins and chocolate covered oranges. Taste is floral and herbal hops, citrus, pine, roasted malt, chocolate, burnt caramel and tropical fruit notes. Body is medium with a dense, bubbly carbonation. Finishes with big floral hops, hop resins, pine notes, citrus fruit, chocolate, roasted malt and dark bread.
Sweet hop dominates aroma. Sweet roasty coffee flavor soms hop. Nice but not too good-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Black pour, beautiful brown head. Great toasty chocolate aroma, delicious chocolaty flavor, quite boozy, smooth, full body.

Bottles from Brewdog Bar, Sheffield. Poured the beers 50:50 together. It is opaque black with a foamy eggshell head. Aroma of pine resin and grass, followed by chocolate, caramel and roasted coffee. Taste is roasted malts with bitter aftertaste. Quite prickly carbonation with a good medium body and some oil. I think I prefer the Yang alone.
Sampled at Northgate Tasting. This tends more towards the dark end of the Black IPA spectrum. 11% though? Cant tell.

Location: 50/50 mix of the 12 oz bottles from Superstar - Huntington, 10/19/14


Aroma: The aroma is roasted malt and some juicy hop, but the roast come through more

Appearance: Pours much like Yin, dark brown-black, with a small light brown head and spotty lace

Flavor: The flavor is sweeter than Yin, a little fruity, some dry roast, and a clean, hoppy finish

Palate: The body is medium-plus, smooth and creamy, very easy drinking considering the ABV

Overall Impression: 
I couldnt resit, the bottles want you to do it, it seemed like most of the rates on here are from mixing, and Im clearly easily susceptible to (imagined) peer pressure. Plus, I needed something to do, as there are only 3 games on in the 4:00 block today. This makes for a nice mix. Somehow the mix is sweeter than either of the beers. I cant explain that, but I swear its true. The Double IPA is a little too sweet, but the Imperial Stout is pretty dry, and thus, I like the Black & Tan even more so than the Black or the Tan separately, even though both are very good on their own.

Bottle into a glass. Pours a deep, inky brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is dirt diapers...not infection style....just way muddled to the point of being disgusting. Taste is is roasty, light bitterness, big bitterness...big unbalanced mess overall. Astringent, vegetal...not great...
draft at Blue Monk, Buffalo. dark black pour, fuller bodied. big roast, dark chocolate, piney hops, boozy, weedy hops. strong. decent

Bottle. Dark black pour, lasting 1/4 inch head and an aroma of earthy dark malt and slightly peppery hops (very similar to the aroma of your above average Black IPA). Flavor is chocolate malt, creamy lactose and good and hoppy on the finish. Solid black IPA, picture a higher alcohol version of Stone Sublimely Self Righteous.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter blackest brown with a light beige head.
Aroma is hops first and roasted sweet malt second.
Flavor flows wonderfully with these combined brews. Have had several times from separate bottles but packaged as one is a stroke of perfection. The sweetness of the stout is prominent but doesnt over shadow the imperial IPA. Great brew!

"The single releases of Yin & Yang encouraged you to drink them solo, and combine the last little bit, which we did. Apparently, they decided to just do it themselves and released this ridiculously huge black and tan as its own beer. Yin and Yang is roasty, super sweet and hoppy all a tthe sa,e time. Covers up the alcohol very well for 11% despite its thickness. A nice way to finish off the night. Better than the IIPA, not as good as the stout was solo, IMO."
See other peoples description. Just here to get a buzz... no elderberry to speak of when combined :-)

(50/50 blend from bottles) Brown pour with a fluffy head. Sweet aroma with a lot of smoke and floral hops. I was prepared for incredibly bitter considering how bitter they were individually but it was actually rather smooth. Sweet and smokey with a light chocolate hint at the end and a bitter aftertaste.

Poured 50/50 from bottles into a snifter. Pours a dark black with a nice foamy white head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, caramel, and dark fruit. Taste is sweet on the tongue with very little bitterness. Heavy bodied beer with moderate carbonation and an oily mouth feel. Nice beer, I would rather have the 2 split though.

On tap at The Avenue Pub, New Orleans. Well, the Yin was on tap as well as the Yang and they were mixed from taps. The aroma is only fair, with the piney notes of the double IPA shining through. Appearance was dominated by the stout, which gives it appearance of a great black IPA. Taste follows the nose and is a tad bit on the bitter side, but I like bitter and enjoyed this combo!

Tap at CBC Brixton. The result is still very dark. Sweet, plummy, prune, fig aroma. Full body, medium carbonation. Lots of dark fruit - prune, raisin, figs - rum, grass, lemon, grapefruit, treacle, wood, pine, some booze... Lovely. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Mixed bottles 50:50. Pours reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma and flavor are dominated by the imperial stout but very well balanced by fruity notes in the aroma and the long biitterness in the flavor. Interesting
Bottles mixed 50:50. Dark with a dark, beige head. Dark malt with the tropical fruits popping through. Great mix.

Mixed from bottles. The darkness of the Yin overwhelms in the colour. Dark brown to almost black. Aroma is a combination of the two beers but the Yang stands out a bit more. You get the hops, citrus, grapefruit and the chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Taste is sweet with a nice bitter hoppy aftertaste. I really like this.

Shared 11.2 oz. bottle poured to snifters, showing a ruby highlighted, darkest brown color, with fairly persistent, bubbly tan head foam, and spots & streaks of clingy lacing. The nose was quite roasted, maybe a touch of dark fruit, bakers chocolate, and some wood & char. The taste was similar notes as the aroma, with hop bitterness that was lingering & dry, fairly hidden alcohol, and a touch of malt sweetness that tickled the tongue. Bold enough, liked it.

Mixed from bottles, 50:50 @ Brewfellas.
Dark color with light hints inside. Smooth roasted aroma. At the beginning it has a weird taste, but as soon as it blends it gets very smooth and balanced. I think I prefer this mixture, than any of the two ones, single. Nice one...and boozy.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2016 Bottle. Black pour, thick light tan head. Roast, citrus, chocolate, coffee, quite an interesting mix. Taste is big roast and coffee up front and then a bit more hoppy bitterness and citrus cuts through. Long coffee finish, stout is dominant but there is still that nice fruitiness there
Keg, mixed myself at Express DLyon, Paris, 3rd July. Not bad, reminded me of an imperial black IPA, prefer the two separately though

Mixed this one myself; I have never seen the pre-mixed version in stores. Smells more IPA than stout, but I can sense the roasty char of the stout trying to come through. The aroma is really like a great black IPA. Malt sweetness still holds up through all of this. Looks just like a stout, with the only possible difference being a slightly lighter head (off-white rather than tan). The taste is spot on - a really well balanced black IPA that has slight hops up front and at the end with great roast and smoky flavor in between. Kind of reminds me of Wookey Jack, but I think its even better tasting. Palate is effervescent enough to be a good IPA yet slick enough to be a good stout. Very interesting. Bonus points for being unique - who else would think of this? I was worried that this was just a strategy to get people to buy two 4-packs, but I really like it. Very well done.

Bottles mixed. The yin quickly overtakes the yang in appearance as expected making it black with a thinner tan head. Aroma is a mix chocolate and roasted malts with grapefruit and floral hops, which is quite nice. Taste is very balanced, not too sweet with a consistent bitterness. Medium body, good carbonation, and smooth / creamy on the palate. Impressive blend.

Surprising. The nose behaves much like Idve expected - lots of malt from both the stout and the IPA halves, with just a faint undercurrent of hops. The taste, however, has behaved... unexpectedly. There appears to be less sweet malt on the outset than was present in either the Yin or the Yang. Its like their sweetnesses didnt add, but the bitter did. I want to try this again with a proper float, but its pretty serviceable just as it is.
The two beers were better sampled together rather than mixed. They were good mixed but much rather they werent.

creamy chocolat, coffee, dark malts, fresh light citrus hops.. very well balanced sweet bitter taste, light carbs, thick oily texture, long dark sweet bitter finish.. interesting complex and delicious

DWG; Pour almost black with a moderate to long lasting, lacing tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, smoked, coffee, licorice, dark dried fruity and dark chocolate. Taste is heavy sweet, light bitter with a warming, sweet chocolate and coffe lasting finish. Body is full, texture is silky thick, carbonation is soft.

Bottles blended. Looks as though you would expect it when getting a Black n Tan. The nose is absolute chock full of those vibrant grapefruit and pine needle notes the Yang gives off. Very in your face with only mild chocolate and roast to back it. Molasses and liquorice play a bigger part in the taste but they are only there to balance out the huge pine driven hops coming through. Very passionfruit and orange forward with mild and sticky tropical fruits throughout. A big hop fueled experience, I really like the idea of buying the two beers and mixing it yourself. I tried it with a little more stout than IPA and I enjoyed it a lot. Kind of rounds it off nicely and gives it some decent balance to such a big beer, Cracking stuff
Keg at Brewdog Edinburgh, mixed yin and yang together. Pours black, pine and smoked chocolate nose, taste has a lot of juicy pine, chocolate, toffee, smoke, quite bitter.

Draught mixed in a taproom. Pours a near black color with a moderate off-white head on there. Nose is only slightly roasty with a moderate amount of hoppiness in the form of grassy and floral notes. Taste is moderately bitter, with a nice amount of roasting. Feels very smooth. Really pleasant mixture.

Mixed the Yin and Yang together. Dark body with low tan head. Aroma has coffee, roasty, dark chocolate, light fruity. Taste has light chocolate sweetness, light fruity roastiness. Made it 50:50 and it has been very well balanced. Long lasting fruity bitterness with astringent end. Body is full, light carbonation. Interesting idea.

Sample from Hoppy Loft. THX to Mathieu87.
Mixed the Yin and Yang together
APPEARANCE: black beer, no foam.
NOSE: little hoppy, some chocolate, oké in general.
TASTE: hoppy, little fruity. Decent overall.

I actually bought the Yin and Yang separately and mixed them together. Absolutely delicious combination and mix of flavors with the IPA and Stout. Thick and rich overflowing head, rich dark color, and inviting aroma!
Mixed together. You get something from each brew. The roastiness, the floral and orange peel along with some chocolate. Medium body light carbonation.

Ins Glas ergießt sich ein sehr dunkelbraunes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr röstmalzig, schokoladig, Kaffee, hopfig bitter. Geschmack röstmalzig, bittere Schokolade, Kaffee, fruchtig herb, bitter.

Bottle. Very dark brown body, small tanned head. Aroma of roasted malt, grapefruit, dark sugar. Taste of coffee, chocolate, rye and piney hops, with fruity yeast esters. Dry feel despite of a sweet taste, burned malt and fruit in finish. Good roasty and fresh aftertaste.

Pours a very dark opaque brown, with a medium tan head and some lace. Aroma is licorice, roasted malt caramel, resin, chocolate and coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, citrus, resin, chocolate, coffee, licorice, burnt, medium-high bitterness and caramel.

Pours an opaque black with a frothy brown head that leaves lacing up the glass. Aroma is a wonderfully complex mix of roasted malts, caramel, resin, chocolate, coffee and citrus. Taste is chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, resin, grapefruit, light nuttiness and smooth bitterness into the finish with a smooth warm alcohol. Moderate carbonation blends a complexity of flavors on this beer and blends all the flavors together with genius.

Created by pouring Yin and Yang in equal parts from the bottle into a crystal glass. Colour is dark brown (the same as the Yin) with heavy brown head that persists; good lacing. Aroma is an elixir that blends the roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and caramel of Yin with the heavy hops, grapefruit, pine, and orange of Yang. The flavour is heavy sweetness against heavy bitterness with the bitterness winning. Crisp ascerbic finish. This works, but the heavy hops are a bit over-powering. As in every couple, one tends to over-power the other.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a lasting tan head with lace. Aromas of roastiness, bitter chocolate, light pine and alcohol. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. 11.2 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a very dark burgundy color. The head is a fluffy looking two finger mocha shade. Im damn impressed by the retention and the lacing it leaves behind. Really damn impressed by the latter especially.

S: Ohmigawd, it smells like someone blended a DIPA and an imperial stout in the same bottle! Both roasted malts and chocolate exist alongside citrusy hops and a toffee-like sweetness. For the uninitiated, anyone whos ever had Storm King will know what to expect here - that quality of roasted tobacco is hard to shake, and I like it.

T: Flavor wise, this first seems to err closer to the DIPA side (Yang) for me. The palate is awakened by leather, candy, and citrusy hops at first, with exhales that are pretty much pure candy-coated hops. It builds a touch of roasted malt and chocolate on the back end, and the more thats sipped, the more this seems to layer itself well: a charred, smoky quality comes out as this sits in the glass. One of my friends likened this to a "black barleywine" and I can see where he was coming from. And even better, the alcohol is well hidden.

M: The feel isnt the creamiest: definitely more like the DIPA portion than the stout one. Even still, its mostly a sweet-finishing beer with just a welcome twinge of dryness right on the back of the palate. Theres a slight prick on the tongue to suggest a hint of heat, picking up ever-so-slightly as it warms up even further. Still, for 11.1%, it drinks rather easily.

O: This isnt the most harmonious blend Ive ever had. But it may as well be the most harmonious pre-made blend Ill likely have. As much as I enjoy this, Id personally rather just buy Yin and Yang separately. Despite my mild reservations, this one is still quite good.

Sometimes the whole is less than the sum of the parts.
